description: A standalone house designed for one family.
A unit within a larger building, typically owned individually.
A rented dwelling unit in a multi-unit building.
A multi-story house attached to other similar houses in a row.
A building with two separate dwelling units.
A movable home that can be transported on wheels.
A housing arrangement where residents own shares in a corporation.
A property rented out for short-term stays, often for vacations.
Property used for business purposes, such as offices or retail spaces.
Property used for manufacturing, warehousing, or other industrial purposes.
Land used for agricultural purposes, including crop and livestock farming.
A large property used for raising livestock, often with a house.
High-end, upscale properties with luxurious amenities.
A property seized by a lender due to non-payment of a mortgage.
Properties purchased for the purpose of generating rental income or capital gains.
Properties with significant historical or architectural value.
Properties located along bodies of water, such as lakes or oceans.
Properties with scenic mountain views.
Residential communities with controlled access and security gates.
Properties located in the suburbs, offering a quieter lifestyle.
